body_html:
ping -> @alicetragedy

So I first used a generator to create all the favicons (based on the .svg file from the design repo). However, after reading a bit more upon favicons, I decided to instead keep it basic. Covering all platforms is barely possible and also not really what I'd consider a useful feature for the teams app.

Having a favicon available in most browsers is an okish goal I'd say, so I skipped everything related to Windows tiles and what not. "Decent" browsers like Chrome use the .png one, so there's also a 32x32 version for all those retina and k displays - since I thought they'd be quite common.

The reason why I moved the files in /assets/images rather then having them in public: "control". It's even recommended like this in the Rails docs.

body:
ping -> @alicetragedy 

So I first used a generator to create **all the favicons** (based on the .svg file from the design repo). However, after reading a bit more upon favicons, I decided to instead keep it basic. Covering all platforms is barely possible and also not really what I'd consider a useful feature for the teams app.

Having a favicon available in most browsers is an okish goal I'd say, so I skipped everything related to Windows tiles and what not. _"Decent"_ browsers like Chrome use the `.png` one, so there's also a `32x32` version for all those retina and <num>k displays - since I thought they'd be quite common.

The reason why I moved the files in `/assets/images` rather then having them in public: *"control"*. It's even recommended like this in [the Rails docs](http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionView/Helpers/AssetTagHelper.html#method-i-favicon_link_tag).
